name: Ionic Bonding
description: Ionic bonding is the electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions formed by the transfer of electrons from a metal to a non-metal.

examples.description: Formation of sodium chloride (NaCl) from sodium (Na) and chlorine (Cl).
Formation of magnesium oxide (MgO) from magnesium (Mg) and oxygen (O₂).

key_points: Ionic bonds form when electrons are transferred from one atom to another.
The metal atom loses electrons to become a positively charged ion (cation).
The non-metal atom gains electrons to become a negatively charged ion (anion).
The oppositely charged ions attract each other, forming a stable ionic compound.
common_misconceptions: Ionic bonds involve the sharing of electrons (this is covalent bonding).
Ionic compounds are always gases at room temperature (many are solids).

practical_activities.title: Investigating the formation of ionic compounds
practical_activities.description: Reacting sodium with chlorine gas to observe the formation of sodium chloride crystals.
safety_notes: Handle sodium metal with care; chlorine gas is flammable.

questions.stem: Which statement best describes ionic bonding?
choices: B: Transfer of electrons from a metal to a non-metal.
C: Movement of protons between atoms.
D: Formation of molecules with covalent bonds.

questions.stem: Explain why ionic compounds generally have high melting points.
Draw a diagram showing the electron transfer in sodium chloride formation.
hints: Show Na atom losing an electron.
Show Cl atom gaining an electron.
